postsData.text: I've done some searching but have been unable to find a face shield design that would accommodate needed protective space around a cochlear implant. We have a medical student who is unable to use any of our hospital's face shield models because it puts too much pressure on the external hardware. Advice/direction would be appreciated. Anyone up for creating a 3D printed version? I'm afraid that's not in my skill set.

postsData.text:
A note on acetate/OHP sheets.
Some sheets appear to be dirty when new. This may just be a layer of soluble glue. Try washing with hot water, then wiping down with blue roll.
In the attached photo, the sheet at the bottom of the picture is how some sheets come, the one at the top is after being rinsed with hot water.
Thanks to Benjamin Babik and Joseph Sanchez for the prodding to see if this was the case.

Looks like 70 celsius isn't enough -- gotta put those cloth masks in boiling water, folks!
I wonder if this is a recent mutation, or if it was always the case.

postsData.text:
For my own production, I tried to optimize the pattern of the #facemask to make it fit so well that there’s no need to touch and straighten it out while wearing. As my #hybridmask might be helpful for others too, I just published the test, instructions, pattern and template: https://www.irisluckhaus.de/hybrid-mask/!
#mask #diymask #showyourmask #masklove #maskpattern #maskmaker #shareamask #wirvsvirus #wearamask #flattenthecurve #stayhome

postsData.text:
Hey all, here is a jig / stencil I designed to make cutting the curves of face shields easier without specialized equipment. Simply place the jig on a flat surface, slide the transparency sheet into the slot and mark with a marker. Repeat for the next corner, then use scissors to cut. Alternatively you could directly cut if you have a cutting surface and sharp enough tool, although please follow safety precautions.
STL file here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4301086

postsData.text:
Home made, snorkel based PAPR. Filter material is melt blown fabric (4+ layers). Runs on a drill battery. I specifically designed this NOT to use an off the shelf HEPA filter because they are flying off the shelves. I have 40M of melt blown fabric. Other materials could be wrapped around the filter cans, as supply dictates. It was fun to watch the design evolve, if I have time I am going to go back to square one and start over with my final concept in mind. I would also like to make a filter box that accepts 1 or 2 KN95 masks as the filter media. Let me know what you think.
P.s. the rubber bands were wayyy to long so that's why it looks kinda janky. Got the right size coming.
STEP file here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1R-YBeJLVtvak6cK4vFvUA7WLjcVAVJ-T
Some parts may not be needed for your application.

postsData.text:
I am considering options for creating a skin-safe, durable seal for reusable filter-fabric face masks. Has anyone tried medical grade silicone rubber sealants/adhesives/caulks like the kind used to create non-slip bra bands and straps? Note that these create a slight ridge with a smooth surface (no peaks like you'd get with caulk), they bond well to the textile, and they are completely washable. What search terms should I use to source these? Any recommendations for related products?
(Edit: to clarify, I'm looking for the adhesive, not straps, please!)

Payment -
Paypal works the easiest

postsData.text: Hey. My husband and I came up with a small idea that seemed worth sharing. 😎 This is a flexible wire strip made by braiding garbage bag twist ties together, and then inserted into a simple cloth mask, so it fits a little tighter and more comfortably across our noses.
postsData.post_text: Hey. My husband and I came up with a small idea that seemed worth sharing. 😎 This is a flexible wire strip made by braiding garbage bag twist ties together, and then inserted into a simple cloth mask, so it fits a little tighter and more comfortably across our noses.
